statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Washington State 49, BYU 46
article.story: SALT LAKE CITY (AP) -- Washington State finally got it right this time. The Cougars were coming off consecutive losses -- a blowout at No. 6 Oklahoma State and a two-point loss to No. 25 Gonzaga -- and used the difficult experiences to pull out a close one in a 49-46 win over Brigham Young on Saturday. "It was good for us because Oklahoma State was just ugly. We wanted to put that one so far behind us," Thomas Kelati said of the 81-29 loss the week before. "Gonzaga, we came back and played good basketball but didn't get the win. At least we were making progress. Then we came in this game, played good basketball and got the win." Kelati led Washington State (4-3) with 15 points and Josh Akognon scored all nine of his points on 3-pointers in the second half to win the battle of the Cougars. Seven of Washington State's nine field goals in the final 20 minutes were 3-pointers, allowing the Cougars to take a lead late and hold off BYU (2-6) at the end. Washington State went from turning the ball over 11 times in the first half to just four turnovers in the second to help make up for a poor shooting performance from just about everywhere inside the 3-point line. "We don't have a lot of inside scoring ability, so we need to take those rhythm shots," said Washington State coach Dick Bennett. "We've shot them all year. This was one of the few times we happened to connect consistently." BYU was playing a home game at the Delta Center, about 45 miles from the Cougar campus in Provo. The game drew an announced crowd of 10,283 and the BYU fans were loud throughout a sloppy game that got exciting at the end. "We knew they could shoot. We got kind of lulled to sleep because they weren't as aggressive in the first half. And we didn't adjust in time," BYU's Austin Ainge said. Ainge, who had 16 points and four assists, missed a tying attempt just before the buzzer after giving BYU hope with a 3-pointer and a layup in the final 18 seconds. Woeful shooting for BYU only got worse in the second half, going from 38.5 percent to 31.8 and finishing just 17-for-48 from the field. Garner Meads had 10 rebounds and Mike Rose added 15 points, but he and Ainge were the only BYU players to score in double figures. Washington State, which trailed by 10 early in the second half, actually had a worse shooting night, going 16-for-49 from the floor. But the seven 3-pointers in the second half were too much for BYU to overcome. Jeff Varem had 11 rebounds and made two clutch free throws with 13 seconds remaining to help seal it. "We knew they were going to have to come after us because we had the lead. So we just had to keep our poise and take care of the ball. Eventually, they'd have to foul us," Kelati said. After Kelati put Washington State up 46-41 on two free throws with 39 seconds left to play, Ainge made it interesting with a 3-pointer that got BYU to 46-44 with 18.2 seconds remaining. BYU fans thought Washington State traveled on the inbounds play, but there was no call and Chris Schlatter called time out to avoid a turnover. Washington State got the ball in on a long pass to Varem, who was immediately fouled by Meads with 13.1 seconds left in the game. Varem hit the first free throw, then the second after a time out to seal it. Ainge added a layup with 7.6 seconds, but Shami Gill was fouled right away and went 1-for-2 from the line to make it a three-point game with 6.7 seconds remaining. Ainge brought the ball up for a final attempt, but it was way off at the buzzer. "I was kind of off balance. I was running full speed and it was off from the beginning," Ainge said.
